summary:
The Security Council:
- Calls on all parties to refrain from offensive actions during disengagement and withdrawal of foreign forces, expressing concern over recent military operations in the Kivus (para 4).
- Demands Rassemblement Congolais pour la DÃ©mocratie demilitarize Kisangani and all parties respect the demilitarization (para 5).
- Demands all parties cease assistance and cooperation with armed groups listed in Annex A, Chapter 9.1 of the Lusaka Ceasefire Agreement (para 6).
- Takes note of plans for the withdrawal of foreign forces and disarmament, demobilization, repatriation, and reintegration (DDRR) of armed groups, and calls for their finalization and implementation (para 7).
- Requests parties to provide operational information to the Joint Military Commission to facilitate UN planning (para 8).
- Encourages the Presidents and Governments of the Democratic Republic of the Congo and Rwanda to intensify dialogue for regional security structures (para 9).
- Condemns recent incursions by armed groups into Rwanda and Burundi (para 10).
- Welcomes dialogue between the Democratic Republic of the Congo and Burundi, and urges all States to bring influence on Burundian armed groups to refrain from violence (para 11).
- Stresses that durable peace in the Democratic Republic of the Congo should not be achieved at the expense of peace in Burundi (para 12).
- Welcomes the announcement of the Inter-Congolese Dialogue and calls on all Congolese parties to commence dialogue (para 13).
- Calls on all parties to address urgent child protection concerns, including DDRR of child soldiers (para 14).
- Condemns massacres and atrocities, and demands an end to human rights and international humanitarian law violations (para 15).
- Reminds parties of their obligations to protect civilian populations under the Fourth Geneva Convention (para 16).
- Condemns attacks against humanitarian organizations and demands perpetrators be brought to justice (para 17).
- Condemns the use of child soldiers and demands an end to recruitment, training, and use of children in armed forces (para 18).
- Calls on parties to ensure access of relief personnel and delivery of humanitarian assistance (para 19).
- Calls on the international community to increase support for humanitarian relief activities (para 20).
- Expresses support for the Expert Panel on the illegal exploitation of natural resources and notes the report's disturbing information (para 21).
